SiteName: Qikiqtaruk (Orca)
community_description: Arctic ecotone from graminoid to shrub dominated
community_species: Salix richardsonii, Equisetum
phenology: Seasonal biomass peak
soil: organic soils and ice rich permafrost on alluvial fan.
disturbance: None known
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Cunliffe et al. In Prep.
Acknowledgements: This work was supported by NERC (NE/M016323/1), and the loan of GNSS equipment from NERC GEF (NERC/GEF:1063 and 1069). The authors wish to thank the Inuvialuit people for permission to work on their traditional lands, and the Yukon Government and Parks for their permission and support of this research (Permit number Inu-02-16). Drone flight operations were authorised by a Special Flight Operations Certificate granted by Transport Canada. We thank Haydn Thomas, Sandra Angers-Blondin Eleanor Walker, John Godlee and Santeri Lehtonen for invaluable assistance with fieldwork
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/M016323/1) awarded to I.H.M.-S., NERC GEF (NERC/GEF:1063 and 1069) to I.H.M.-S. and A.M.C.
Acknowledgements_Permission: Yukon Government and Parks (Permit: Inu-02-16), The Inuvialuit People
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Haydn Thomas, Sandra Angers-Blondin, Eleanor Walker, John Godlee, Santeri Lehtonen
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
sky_conditions: 5 - Cumulus over most of sky (sun not obscured)
drone_and_sensor: Tarot 680 Pro hexacopter (Sony alpha6000 camera and Sony SEL 20 mm F2.8 lens)
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud edited manually to remove plot infrasturcture, looks okay.

Investigators: Miguel L. Villarreal, Caroline A. Havrilla
SiteName: SAGE-E; Beef Basin, Utah
community_description: Wyoming black Sagebrush with blue grama grasses
community_species: Artemesia nova, bouteloua gracilis, Hesperostipa comata and gutierrezia sarothrae
phenology: Maximum greenness for native species was occurring during collection, which is typical in late spring/early summer of this region
soil: Ignacio-Leanto fine sandy loams
disturbance: Evidence of livestock
Notes_on_survey_harvest: See: Poitras et al. 2018 in Journal of Arid Environments, which provides further details on the vegetation communities and our recent remote sensing research in this study area (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jaridenv.2017.12.008). We also have a UAS paper in prep using these study plots to look at biocrust/plant diversity relationships which should be out in 2019, I will update with publication info when available. Wind speed between 0-3 m s-1.

SiteName: Lakeside Campus, University of Worcester
community_description: The site was sown at some unknown point in the relatively recent past, using a pasture-mixture. It therefore isnt really possible to exactly define the plant community, but by using the British National Vegetation Classification (NVC) it would be pretty close to the MG6-community. The MG6 is a mesotrophic grassland community which is a well-drained permanent pasture or meadow. In this community there are 6 constant species (species always found), in our plot we have 4 of these 6 species (Festuca rubra, Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne, Trifolium repens but not Cerastium fontanum or Cynosurus cristatus), also note here that 3 of the 4 constant species we have are the most abundant of all our species (not Holcus lanatus because we only had a few individuals).
community_species:
Major species present:
*Festuca rubra
*Lolium perenne
*Poa annua
*Medicago lupulina
*Trifolium repens
Not major cover, but much higher than surrounding veg:
*Rumex obtusifolius
More detailed species list can be provided if needed
phenology:
Festuca rubra - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Lolium perenne - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Poa annua - finished flowering
Medicago lupulina - flowering (slightly declining)
Trifolium repens - flowering
Rumex obtusifolius - seeds fully ripe
soil:
Don't know exact type or depth for now, but...
According to Edina Geology:
Loam texture, firm strength, <10% CaCO3..
UKSO: Slightly acid loamy soil
disturbance: Cropland converted to pasture (ca. 10 years ago?). Circular plot not cut this spring/summer. Surrounding grass is cut on a regular basis with a mower. No cattle present.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: 12 plots were taken within the un-cut grassland circle. 4 plots were taken outside the circle from the recently mowed surrounding grassland. The weather had been quite warm/sunny/dry leading up to the date of harvesting, so the grass looked very dry and some of the weeds seemed almost burnt (e.g. clover flowers). Most likely due to heavy winds earlier some of the grass was lying a bit flat (got lodged). Climate observations were from the Pershore weather station. Wind speed between 0-2 ms-1.
Acknowledgements: University of Worcester. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks good, Corner coordinates look good (but possibly ca. 10-15 cm low).

In this community there are 6 constant species (species always found), in our plot we have 4 of these 6 species (Festuca rubra, Holcus lanatus, Lolium perenne, Trifolium repens but not Cerastium fontanum or Cynosurus cristatus), also note here that 3 of the 4 constant species we have are the most abundant of all our species (not Holcus lanatus because we only had a few individuals).
community_species:
Major species present:
*Festuca rubra
*Lolium perenne
*Poa annua
*Medicago lupulina
*Trifolium repens
Not major cover, but much higher than surrounding veg:
*Rumex obtusifolius
More detailed species list can be provided if needed
phenology:
Festuca rubra - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Lolium perenne - after peak but before they stopped flowering
Poa annua - finished flowering
Medicago lupulina - flowering (slightly declining)
Trifolium repens - flowering
Rumex obtusifolius - seeds fully ripe
soil:
Don't know exact type or depth for now, but...
According to Edina Geology:
Loam texture, firm strength, <10% CaCO3..
UKSO: Slightly acid loamy soil
disturbance: Cropland converted to pasture (ca. 10 years ago?). Circular plot not cut this spring/summer. Surrounding grass is cut on a regular basis with a mower. No cattle present.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: 12 plots were taken within the un-cut grassland circle. 4 plots were taken outside the circle from the recently mowed surrounding grassland. The weather had been quite warm/sunny/dry leading up to the date of harvesting, so the grass looked very dry and some of the weeds seemed almost burnt (e.g. clover flowers). Most likely due to heavy winds earlier some of the grass was lying a bit flat (got lodged). Climate observations were from the Pershore weather station. Wind speed between 0-2 ms-1.
Acknowledgements: University of Worcester. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks good, Corner coordinates look good (but possibly ca. 10-15 cm low).

SiteName: Billy Creek Site #1, Craig Mountain Wildlife Management Area, Idaho
community_description: Hells Canyon grassland. Perennial grass restoration site with some invasive annual plants
community_species: Pseudoroegnaria spicata, Ventanata dubia, Bromus tectorum, Helianthella uniflora, Amsinckia spp., Conyza canadensis
phenology: Pseudoroegneria spicata has set seed, but is still green. Ventenata, Bromus, and Amsinckia were fully scenesced. Helianthella and and Conyza were in full flower.
soil: USDA Soil Series: Limekiln very gravelly silt loam to 60cm. Quick field verification, but no soil pit dug.
disturbance: Historically used as pasture and for hay production. No livestock grazing for at least 25 years. Approx. 10 years ago herbicide treated for annual invasives and restoration seeding of bluebunch wheatgrass.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Plots harvested over Pseudoroegneria spicata only
Acknowledgements: Access to the site was provided by Idaho Department of Fish and Game
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Acknowledgements_Permission: Idaho Department of Fish and Game
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates look plausible.

SiteName: Billy Creek Site #2, Craig Mountain Wildlife Management Area, Idaho
community_description: Hells Canyon grassland. Perennial grass restoration site with some invasive annual plants
community_species: Pseudoroegnaria spicata, Ventanata dubia, Bromus tectorum, Helianthella uniflora, Amsinckia spp., Conyza canadensis
phenology: Pseudoroegneria spicata has set seed, but is still green. Ventenata, Bromus, and Amsinckia were fully scenesced. Helianthella and and Conyza were in full flower.
soil: USDA Soil Series: Limekiln very gravelly silt loam to 60cm. Quick field verification, but no soil pit dug.
disturbance: Historically used as pasture and for hay production. No livestock grazing for at least 25 years. Approx. 10 years ago herbicide treated for annual invasives and restoration seeding of bluebunch wheatgrass.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Plots harvested over Pseudoroegneria spicata only.

SiteName: Hartlebury Common, Worcestershire
community_description: Acid grassland/heath mosaic community interspersed with western gorse and locally-frequent patches of bracken. Some mixed scrub, largely made up of broom, birch saplings, bramble. So most likely British National Vegetation Classification (NVC) class H8
community_species: Pteridium aquilinum, Calluna Vulagris, Ulex Gallii U. europaeus, Cytisus scoparius, Rubus fruticosus, Betula spp. - saplings, Festuca ovina, Erica cinerea, Agrostis capillaris, Hypnum cupressiforme, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus
phenology: Pteridium aquilinum - ?, Calluna Vulagris - flowering, Ulex Gallii  flowering, U. europaeus - flowering, Cytisus scoparius - flowering, Rubus fruticosus - flowering, Betula spp. - saplings, Festuca ovina  Seeds, Erica cinerea  flowering, Agrostis capillaris - ?, Hypnum cupressiforme (?) - ?, Rhytidiadelphus squarrosus - ?
soil: Not observed on site, but According to Edina Geology: Loam, loose strength, no CaCO3 classification, but probably low. UKSO: Sand to Sandy Loam Arenosol
disturbance: Current management: Restoration management to heathland in the form of scrub control primarily targeting the denser stands of mixed scrub. As well as this, the removal of saplings and many of the standard trees is also undertaken. Repeat follow up clearance and treatment will be required in subsequent years to supplement grazing.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: (Met Data from MetOffice Pershore weather station). Wind speed between 0-2 m s-1.
Acknowledgements: Worcester County Council and Natural England for allowing access to Hartlebury Common and in particular Martin Barnett for help with gorse harvesting. James Atkins for assistance with data collection.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NA
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
sky_conditions: 5 - Cumulus over most of sky (sun not obscured)
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Richard Brazier, Karen Anderson, Fabio Boschetti
SiteName: Harvest site at Willard Juniper Savannah (US-WJS), New Mexico
community_species: Juniperus Monosperma, Bouteloa Eripoda
phenology: Survey and harvest was carried out at the beginning of October, roughly one month after the monsoon season. The trees were close to seasonal peak biomass condition. Weather was turning cold with the beginning of Autumn.
soil: Inceptisol (well drained with <25% clay content). Based on USA Soil Survey Maps.
disturbance: Occasional grazing from cows.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: See Cunliffe et al. 2020 (doi: 10.3389/fpls.2020.00094).
Acknowledgements: We received permission from the landowner (Leroy Humpfries), and from the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to conduct drone operations. We are grateful to the technical staff of Sevilleta and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the measurement campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to R.E.B., A.M.C., K.A., S.S.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, but corner coordinates are all ca 5 cm low (within expected error, but will bias analysis).

Investigators: Simon Power, Michael Cramer, Julian Smit
SiteName: Protea Farm
community_description: Montagu Shale Fynbos. Sclerophyllous shrub dominated with a few succulents.
community_species: Dominant species: Elytropappus rhinocerotis. Species known to occur in vegetation type: Protea nitida, Protea laurifolia, Protea neriifolia, Protea repens, Dodonaea viscosa var. angustifolia, Lebeckia cytisoides, Leucadendron rubrum, Athrixia heterophylla subsp. heterophylla, Cliffortia ramosissima, Leucadendron salignum, Leucadendron salignum, Leucadendron teretifolium, Leucospermum calligerum, Protea humifloraProtea lorifolia, Protea scolopendriifolia, Protea sulphurea, Senecio pinifolius, Ursinia heterodonta, Vexatorella obtusata subsp. obtusata, Geissorhiza ornithogaloides subsp. marlothii, Ixia leipoldtii, Romulea sphaerocarpa, Wurmbea compacta, Ehrharta calycina, Ehrharta capensis, Ischyrolepis capensis, Karroochloa purpurea, Tribolium hispidum, Ixia gloriosa, Amphithalea pageae, Aspalathus rostrata, Lotononis argentea, Stirtonanthus insignis
phenology: Full leaf out following spring.
soil: Hard, clay, shale-derived soils
disturbance: No known fire in > 10 years, although surrounding area burnt 1 year prior.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: "Harvest completed by Simon, Michael and Julian in one day. 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying.  See Mucina, L. & Rutherford, M.C. (eds) (2006) The vegetation of South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. Strelitzia, 19. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria for further description of vegetation type." Wind speed Avg 3.9 m/s 64 degrees and Gust 8.6 m/s direction 76 degrees. Light breeze.
Acknowledgements: University of Cape Town research council award.
Acknowledgements_Funding: University of Cape Town award to S.C.P., J.S. and M.D.C.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

Investigators: Simon Power, Michael Cramer, Julian Smit
SiteName: Drie Kuilen Nature Reserve
community_description: Matjiesfontein Shale Renosterveld. Sclerophyllous shrub dominated with a few succulents.
community_species: Dominant species: Pteronia paniculata. Species known to occur in vegetation type: Elytropappus rhinocerotis, Aspalathus alpestris, Asparagus capensis var. capensis, Athanasia flexuosa, Athanasia flexuosa, Chrysocoma ciliata, Chrysocoma ciliata, Chrysocoma ciliata, Chrysocoma oblongifolia, Eriocephalus ericoides subsp. ericoides, Euryops cuneatus, Euryops imbricatus, Euryops microphyllus, Helichrysum simulans, Oedera genistifoliaPasserina truncata subsp. truncata, Pteronia sordida, Antimima dasyphylla, Cotula macroglossa, Foveolina dichotoma, Lepidium desertorum, Rhynchopsidium sessiliflorum, Rumex lanceolatus, Ursinia nana, Ursinia nana, Chlorophytum lewisiae, Gethyllis campanulata, Romulea atrandra, Romulea atrandra, Romulea atrandra, Romulea sphaerocarpa, Romulea tortuosa, Romulea tortuosa, Romulea tortuosa, Trachyandra thyrsoidea, Crassula lanceolata subsp. lanceolata, Bromus pectinatus, Ehrharta calycina, Ehrharta capensis, Ehrharta delicatula, Hyparrhenia hirta, Hypodiscus sulcatus, Pentaschistis rigidissima, Lotononis comptonii, Disa cochlearis, Hesperantha truncatula, Romulea malaniae
phenology: Majority of individuals with new leaves following spring.
soil: Hard, clayey and stoney, shale-derived soils
disturbance: No known fire in > 10 years.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: "Harvest completed by Simon, Michael and Julian in one day. 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying.  See Mucina, L. & Rutherford, M.C. (eds) (2006) The vegetation of South Africa, Lesotho and Swaziland. Strelitzia, 19. South African National Biodiversity Institute, Pretoria for further description of vegetation type." Avg 4.2 m/s 263 degrees and Gust 8.4 m/s direction 301 degrees (Light breeze with gusts).
Acknowledgements: University of Cape Town research council award. Drie Kuilen Nature Reserve for providing permission for sampling.
Acknowledgements_Funding: University of Cape Town award to S.C.P., J.S. and M.D.C.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

SiteName: WGEW (Walnut Gulch Experimental Watershed)
community_description: Shrub-dominated with some perennial grass presence
community_species: Larrea tridentata, Parthenium incanum, Flourensia cernua, Zinnia acerosa, Muhlenbergia porteri, Hilaria belangeri, Aristida L.
phenology: Shrubs were leafed out, but past flowering . Grasses were showing inflorescence and dried out.
soil: Pedrogosa soil, Limy Upland ecological site
disturbance: un-grazed for 30 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest completed in a single day, with 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying. Drying occurred in small groups due to oven size restrictions.  Only the target species was harvested from each plot. Example: C1 (only the LATR2 - creosote bush) was clipped for biomass. This time was definitely past peak of the growing season.  DJI Phantom 4 Pro v2.0.

SiteName: WGEW (Walnut Gulch Experimental Watershed)
community_description: Shrub-dominated with some perennial grass presence
community_species: Larrea tridentata, Parthenium incanum, Flourensia cernua, Zinnia acerosa, Muhlenbergia porteri, Hilaria belangeri, Aristida L.
phenology: Shrubs were leafed out, but past flowering . Grasses were showing inflorescence and dried out.
soil: Pedrogosa soil, Limy Upland ecological site
disturbance: un-grazed for 30 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest completed in a single day, with 100% of harvested material returned to lab for drying. Drying occurred in small groups due to oven size restrictions.  Only the target species was harvested from each plot. Example: C1 (only the LATR2 - creosote bush) was clipped for biomass. This time was definitely past peak of the growing season.  DJI Phantom 4 Pro v2.0.

SiteName: Harvest plot 2 (HAR2), Sevilleta Grassland (US-SEG), New Mexico
community_species: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at the end of February. All of the species were in dormant phase.
soil: Turney loams overlaying a welldeveloped petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45m below the surface
disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. Very windy during survey.
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Breahna Gillespie
SiteName: Sky Oaks Chaparral, California (analouge for SO2)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Adenostoma fasciculatum, Adenostoma sparsifolium, Ceanothus Perplexans
phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
disturbance: Wildfire in 2003 ('Cyote fire'). Age before wildfire: 80 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 2 days: 18th and 19th March 2019. references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet
Acknowledgements: We received permission from SDSU Research Foundation and from the site's PI (Walter Oechel) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to Richard Brazier, Walter Oechel and the SDSU Global Change Research Group for their support during the field campaign.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to R.E.B., A.M.C., K.A., S.S.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud is a bit sparse over the plant. Corners are ca. 3 cm high.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Breahna Gillespie
SiteName: Sky Oaks Chaparral, California (analouge for SO2)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Adenostoma fasciculatum, Adenostoma sparsifolium, Ceanothus Perplexans
phenology: Survey and harvest were carried out at in the middle of March. The region is the wettest in ca. 20 years, with large responses from these water-limited ecosystems. I.e. most vascular plant are growing extremly well. There had been a substantial rain event just a few days prior to the survey.
soil: Soil texture class: Sandy loam. Soil taxonomy: Ultic Haploxeroll (Soil taxonomy from Moreno and Oechel (1992))
disturbance: Wildfire in 2003 ('Cyote fire'). Age before wildfire: 80 years
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest was conducted over 2 days: 18th and 19th March 2019. references: Fabio Boschetti, Richard Brazier, Brehana Gillespie. NB. Litter was measured seperatly, and is available in the project spreadsheet

SiteName: RCEW-WBS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - Wyoming big sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Tetradymia canescens, Chrysothamnus viscidiflorus, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Elymus elymoides, Poa secunda, Bromus tectorum, Phlox longifolia, Astragalus cusickii, Antennaria dimorpha, Crepis acuminata, Zigadenus paniculatus
phenology: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis =just past peak greenness, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata = soft dough, Elymus elymoides = soft dough, Poa secunda = hard seed
additional_species_in_plot: ARTRW8, PHLO2, ELEL5, POSE, PHLO2, PSSP6,CHVI8
soil: Glasgow loam, 0-30% slope, Fine, smectitic, mesic Xeric Haplargids ('Glasgow soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion as a consequence of localized, pocket gopher disturbance. Last wildfire was likely in the mid-1930s.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016). NB. Convergent images were taken at a 65 degree angle rather than the 25 degrees target angle.
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are ca. 4 cm low

KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Tetradymia canescens, Chrysothamnus viscidiflorus, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Elymus elymoides, Poa secunda, Bromus tectorum, Phlox longifolia, Astragalus cusickii, Antennaria dimorpha, Crepis acuminata, Zigadenus paniculatus
phenology: Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis =just past peak greenness, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata = soft dough, Elymus elymoides = soft dough, Poa secunda = hard seed
soil: Glasgow loam, 0-30% slope, Fine, smectitic, mesic Xeric Haplargids ('Glasgow soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion as a consequence of localized, pocket gopher disturbance. Last wildfire was likely in the mid-1930s.

phenology: The vegetation growing season period is from June to October
soil: Umbrisol; soil depth ranges from 30 to 50 cm
disturbance: None known
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. Image quality is sub-optimal (motion blur, some under/over exposues).
Acknowledgements: This study was financially supported by the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness, and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), in the framework of the GESFIRE (AGL2013-48189-C2-1-R) and FIRESEVES (AGL2017-86075-C2-1-R) projects; and by the Regional Government of Castilla y Len in the framework of the FIRECYL (LE033U14) and SEFIRECYL (LE001P17) projects. J.M. Fernndez-Guisuraga is supported by a predoctoral fellowship from the Spanish Ministry of Education (FPU16/03070)
Acknowledgements_Funding: GESFIRE (AGL2013-48189-C2-1-R), FIRESEVES (AGL2017-86075-C2-1-R), FIRECYL (LE033U14) and SEFIRECYL (LE001P17) awarded to J.M.F.-G., L.C. and S.S.-S. FPU16/03070 awarded to J.M.F.-G.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

SiteName: RCEW-LOS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - low sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Artemisia arbuscula, Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Festuca idahoensis, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Poa secunda, Elymus elymoides, Bromus tectorum, Lupinus argenteus, Phlox longifolia, Astragulus cuskii, Epilobium minutum, Eriogonum microthecum
phenology: Artemisia arbuscula = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough
soil: Searla gravelly loam, 0-30% slope, Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Calcic Argixerolls ('Searla soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Very minor amount of cheatgrass (BRTE) invasion. Last wildfire was at least prior to mid-1930s
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016)
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corner coordinates are okay.

SiteName: RCEW-LOS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - low sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Artemisia arbuscula, Artemisia tridentata wyomingensis, Festuca idahoensis, Pseudoroegneria spicata spicata, Poa secunda, Elymus elymoides, Bromus tectorum, Lupinus argenteus, Phlox longifolia, Astragulus cuskii, Epilobium minutum, Eriogonum microthecum
phenology: Artemisia arbuscula = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough

SiteName: Harvest plot 2 (HAR2), Sevilleta Grassland (US-SEG), New Mexico
community_species: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.
phenology: Unknown
soil: Turney loams overlaying a welldeveloped petrocalcic horizon located ~0.250.45m below the surface
disturbance: Extreme cold event in 2011; wildfire a long time ago (?)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Harvest conducted in one morning, between 0730 and 1030. This harvest follows a very wet winter/spring in this water limited ecosystem.
Acknowledgements: We received permission from Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge and form the site's PI (Marcy Litvak) to carry out drone operations. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff and to Marcy Litvak for their support during the field campaign

SiteName: Nancy's Gulch, RCEW-MBS (Reynolds Creek Experimental Watershed - mountain big sagebrush)
KoppenCC_long: Mediterranean: mild with dry, hot summer
community_species: Artemisia tridentata vaseyana, Symphoricarpos oreophilus utahensis, Bromus marginatus, Poa pratensis, Elymus elymoides, Lupinus argenteus, Eriogonum heracleoides, Achillea millefolium, Crepis acuminata, Polygonum douglasii
phenology: Artemisia tridentata vaseyana = just past peak greenness, Elymus elymoides = soft dough
additional_species_in_plot: ARTRV, LUAR3, ERHE2, CRAC2,BRMA4, POSE, ELEL5
soil: Gabica cobbly gravelly loam, 0-30% slope, Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Lithic Argixerolls ('Gabica soil series' in the USDA taxonomy)
disturbance: Fairly intact native community. Last wildfire unknown but probably prior to mid-1930s
Notes_on_survey_harvest: DJI Phantom 4 with stock 12MP camera (purchased in 2016).
Notes_on_plot: In some plots, non-target biomass comprises a large (up to 40%) proporation of the AGB total. This plot was on the very edge of the surveyed area of interest, so might not have been adequatly captured in images. Outside of Nadir surveys!
Acknowledgements: Funded by USDA Agricultural Research Service, Landowner = USDI Bureau of Land Management (Federal) sampled with permission provided under an existing research MOU.
Acknowledgements_Funding: USDA Agricultural Research Service
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Ben Porter, Alex Boehm, Jordan Johnston
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks plausible, corners appear 10 cm low.

Investigators: Sergio A.Vargas Z (S.A.Vargas Z); Craig Tweedie (C.E. Tweedie)
SiteName: Utqiagvik (formerly Barrow), Alaska
community_description: Mixed vascular and non-vascular composition (Bryophytes, Deciduous shrubs, Forbs, Graminoids, Lichens), ranging from dry-dwarf shrub-graminoid tundra to wet graminoid tundra
community_species: Arctophila fulva, Carex aquatilis and other
phenology: peak phenological stage for both Arctophila and Carex
soil: Continuous permafrost, from dry heath to wet meadow
disturbance: undisturbed tundra landscape
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. INPUT IMAGE QUALITY IS POOR. The site is situated on the edge of and within a dry lake basin consisting mostly of wet graminoid tundra. Peak season is characterized by moist to wet soil conditions with standing surface water in most cases, an ideal state for Arctophila. The tendency for this species to mostly thrive alone made it a target taxa for this study as this landscape is typically composed of a mixture of species within a small area making up the complex landscape plant communities. Vegetation was a mixture between 10 and 11 on the IGBP classes. Biomass dried at ca. 60 degrees C. There was some surface water in most plots. The first flight started at 11:52 am local AK (19:52 UTC) and the last flight ended at 12:35 pm local AK (20:35 UTC).
Acknowledgements: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA, Julio Ceniceros, Mariana Orejel
Acknowledgements_Funding: NSF (#1836861), NASA ABoVE award number: NNX17AC58A
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks plausible, corners appear good.

Investigators: Sergio A.Vargas Z (S.A.Vargas Z); Craig Tweedie (C.E. Tweedie)
SiteName: Utqiagvik (formerly Barrow), Alaska
community_description: Mixed vascular and non-vascular composition (Bryophytes, Deciduous shrubs, Forbs, Graminoids, Lichens), ranging from dry-dwarf shrub-graminoid tundra to wet graminoid tundra
community_species: Arctophila fulva, Carex aquatilis and other
phenology: peak phenological stage for both Arctophila and Carex
soil: Continuous permafrost, from dry heath to wet meadow
disturbance: undisturbed tundra landscape
Notes_on_survey_harvest: NB. INPUT IMAGE QUALITY IS POOR. The site is situated on the edge of and within a dry lake basin consisting mostly of wet graminoid tundra. Peak season is characterized by moist to wet soil conditions with standing surface water in most cases, an ideal state for Arctophila. The tendency for this species to mostly thrive alone made it a target taxa for this study as this landscape is typically composed of a mixture of species within a small area making up the complex landscape plant communities. Vegetation was a mixture between 10 and 11 on the IGBP classes. Biomass dried at ca. 60 degrees C. There was some surface water in most plots. The first flight started at 11:52 am local AK (19:52 UTC) and the last flight ended at 12:35 pm local AK (20:35 UTC).
Acknowledgements: UIC, NSF (#1836861), NASA, Julio Ceniceros, Mariana Orejel
Acknowledgements_Funding: NSF (#1836861), NASA ABoVE award number: NNX17AC58A
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks plausible, corners appear good.

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 1
community_species: Bryophytes
phenology: Unknown (Summer peak)
soil: raw soil
disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 10 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1997 and 2009).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Suboptimal images, underexposed! Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be seperated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values).
Notes_on_plot: Based on ID from the photos, the briophytes seem to belong to the two genus Racomitrium and Pohlia (starlike growth with white tips = Racomitrien, upright growth with red stalks = most probably Pohlia)
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).
Acknowledgements_Funding: EU Horizon 2020 grant No. 776681 (PHUSICOS)
Acknowledgements_Assistance: Barbara Pachler, Ulrich Zangerl, Gerald Griesebner
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks good, corners appear ca. 7 cm high.

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 2
community_description: Partially covered with moss and small grasses, dominating plant is the thistle
community_species: Cirsium spinosissimum, Bryophyta
phenology: full-grown and in full bloom
soil: raw soil
disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 70 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1922 and 1971).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Review of UAV images (by Andy) suggests that many images are also quite dark (underexposed). Ii appears that camera settings were fixed despite variable illumination conditions. At KS2, nadir flights were conducted at ca. 10:00 (UTC) and oblique flights at ca. 13:50 UTC (gap due to poor weather). Camera angles appear sub-optimal, esp. on non-nadir images; this might have been very steep ground? NB. Only 12 GCPs were geolocated. Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be separated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values), ca. 15 km distant.
Notes_on_plot: This sample started decomposing before being dried in the lab, so the AGB provides only a minimum estimate of the AGB.
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).

Acknowledgements_Assistance: Barbara Pachler, Ulrich Zangerl, Gerald Griesebner

Investigators: Hannes Wirnsberger, Andrew Cunliffe, Stefan Haselberger, Sabine Kraushaar
SiteName: Kaunertal Site 2
community_description: Partially covered with moss and small grasses, dominating plant is the thistle
community_species: Cirsium spinosissimum, Bryophyta
phenology: full-grown and in full bloom
soil: raw soil
disturbance: This site has been free of ice for ca. 70 years (glacier retreat sometime between 1922 and 1971).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Review of UAV images (by Andy) suggests that many images are also quite dark (underexposed). Ii appears that camera settings were fixed despite variable illumination conditions. At KS2, nadir flights were conducted at ca. 10:00 (UTC) and oblique flights at ca. 13:50 UTC (gap due to poor weather). Camera angles appear sub-optimal, esp. on non-nadir images; this might have been very steep ground? NB. Only 12 GCPs were geolocated. Harvesting completed in 1 day, 100 % of harvested material returned to the lab, moss had to be separated from soil before drying. MAT and MAP from http://tirolatlas.uibk.ac.at/, from the climate station Kaunertal-Feichten (longterm average values), ca. 15 km distant.
Acknowledgements: This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 776681  (PHUSICOS). You do not need to acknowledge any people or organisations for permission to harvest. For assistance with collecting this dataset you should acknowledge Barbara Pachler (UNIVIE), Ulrich Zangerl (UNIVIE) and Mag. Gerald Griesebner (University of Salzburg).

Investigators: Ji Proek; Kateina Gdulov; Petra mov
SiteName: Doupovsk hory (Radoov)
community_description: shrubland consisting of a mosaic of herbaceous and shrub vegetation
community_species: Shrubs (Crataegus sp., Prunus spinosa, Rosa canina), Acidophilous dry meandows (Achillea millefolium, Agrimonia eupatoria, Galium sp., Alchemilla vulgaris, Fragaria sp.)
phenology: Late biomass peak (fully developed leaves/foliage; without ripe fruits)
soil: Cambisols and Podzols (according to a national database)
disturbance: Non-known (limited long-term information, but there wasnt any evidently disturbance in last decade. This area is accessible to wild animals, which can browse on the shrubs but that was not abundantly evident (habit (shape) of the shrubs was natural, unaffected; not like a bonsai). The current form of the locality is result of natural succession).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Locality already used in study: Proek, J., & mov, P. (2019). UAV for mapping shrubland vegetation: Does fusion of spectral and vertical information derived from a single sensor increase the classification accuracy? International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation, 75, 151-162. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2018.10.009. Roles: Ji Proek: Organization and preparing of our part of the experiment (including the laboratory/drying procedure), performing of the UAV flight, field work and harvesting. Petra mov: Managing and funding agreement of our part of the experiment, ensure permission and consulting with respect to expertise knowledge of locality Kateina Gdulov: RTK GNSS survey (harvested plots, UAV ground control markers) and GNSS data processing, field work and harvesting, botanic expertise). Note that sampled individuals all appear fairly small, and so might not be representative of the full size range these species can cover. First survey/flight was performed between 11:00  11:20 UTC (nadir camera orientation) and second survey/flight was performed during 11:28  11:48 UTC (25/75 camera orientation).
Acknowledgements: Funding by Department of Applied Geoinformatics and Spatial Planning and Spatial Science in Ecology and Environment group (Faculty of Environmental Sciences, Czech University of Life Sciences Prague, Praha  Suchdol, Czech Republic)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Czech University of Life Sciences to J.P.
Acknowledgements_Permission: Nature Conservation Agency of the Czech Republic
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks highly plausible, and corners look highly plausible.

International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation, 75, 151-162. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jag.2018.10.009. Roles: Ji Proek: Organization and preparing of our part of the experiment (including the laboratory/drying procedure), performing of the UAV flight, field work and harvesting. Petra mov: Managing and funding agreement of our part of the experiment, ensure permission and consulting with respect to expertise knowledge of locality Kateina Gdulov: RTK GNSS survey (harvested plots, UAV ground control markers) and GNSS data processing, field work and harvesting, botanic expertise). Note that sampled individuals all appear fairly small, and so might not be representative of the full size range these species can cover. First survey/flight was performed between 11:00  11:20 UTC (nadir camera orientation) and second survey/flight was performed during 11:28  11:48 UTC (25/75 camera orientation).

Investigators: Ji Proek; Kateina Gdulov; Petra mov
SiteName: Doupovsk hory (Radoov)
community_description: shrubland consisting of a mosaic of herbaceous and shrub vegetation
community_species: Shrubs (Crataegus sp., Prunus spinosa, Rosa canina), Acidophilous dry meandows (Achillea millefolium, Agrimonia eupatoria, Galium sp., Alchemilla vulgaris, Fragaria sp.)
phenology: Late biomass peak (fully developed leaves/foliage; without ripe fruits)
soil: Cambisols and Podzols (according to a national database rather than field observations)
disturbance: Non-known (limited long-term information, but there wasnt any evidently disturbance in last decade. This area is accessible to wild animals, which can browse on the shrubs but that was not abundantly evident (habit (shape) of the shrubs was natural, unaffected; not like a bonsai). The current form of the locality is result of natural succession).
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Locality already used in study: Proek, J., & mov, P. (2019). UAV for mapping shrubland vegetation: Does fusion of spectral and vertical information derived from a single sensor increase the classification accuracy? Petra mov: Managing and funding agreement of our part of the experiment, ensure permission and consulting with respect to expertise knowledge of locality Kateina Gdulov: RTK GNSS survey (harvested plots, UAV ground control markers) and GNSS data processing, field work and harvesting, botanic expertise). Note that sampled individuals all appear fairly small, and so might not be representative of the full size range these species can cover. First survey/flight was performed between 11:00  11:20 UTC (nadir camera orientation) and second survey/flight was performed during 11:28  11:48 UTC (25/75 camera orientation).

SiteName: SEG Harvest Area 3, Sevilleta LTER, New Mexico
community_species: Bouteloua eriopoda, Bouteloua gracilis, Yucca glauca, Gutierrezia sarothrae, Opuntia, etc.

Investigators: Andrew Cunliffe, Fabio Boschetti, Cameron McIntire
SiteName: Deer Canyon Preserve, Mountainair, New Mexico
community_species: Juniper monosperma, Pinus edulis,Bouteloua gracilis, cactia (esp. imbricarta) and other grasses
phenology: Needles are fully emerged, and likely finished with expansion.
soil: Stony loam (AKA Turkeysprings stony loam), typically with 10-40% slopes (based on https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/App/WebSoilSurvey.aspx)
disturbance: Other (non-sampled) pinion in the area exhibited signs of bark beetle infestation, no obvious evidence of wildfire? Can you check with Marcy on this?) -Yes Other (non-sampled) pine trees in this site exhibited indications of a bark beetle infestation, which may have occured in 2011 (TBC)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Cameron McIntire and Nick Smith. Paired with the US-MPJ fluxtower site run by Marcy Litvak
Acknowledgements: We received permission from the Deer Canyon Preserve. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff for their support during the field campaign

soil: Stony loam (AKA Turkeysprings stony loam), typically with 10-40% slopes (based on https://websoilsurvey.sc.egov.usda.gov/App/WebSoilSurvey.aspx)
disturbance: Other (non-sampled) pinion in the area exhibited signs of bark beetle infestation, no obvious evidence of wildfire? Can you check with Marcy on this?) -Yes Other (non-sampled) pine trees in this site exhibited indications of a bark beetle infestation, which may have occured in 2011 (TBC)
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Cameron McIntire and Nick Smith. Paired with the US-MPJ fluxtower site run by Marcy Litvak
Acknowledgements: We received permission from the Deer Canyon Preserve. We are grateful to the Sevilleta's technical staff for their support during the field campaign
Acknowledgements_Funding: NERC (NE/R00062X/1) awarded to R.E.B., A.M.C., K.A., S.S.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks excellent, and corners look plausible.

SiteName: Site C (C-SAND, Jornada LTER, New Mexico)
community_description: Creosote-dominated bajada, with some herbacious plants (grasses and forbs) and some cacti.
community_species: Larrea tridentata, some Cylindropuntia imbricata
phenology: Leaves  on, no inflorescence.
soil: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, thermic Ustic Haplocalcid
disturbance: No known recent disturbance. C-SAND site located on NMSU Chihuahuan Desert Research Center has been excluded from domestic grazing since at least the 1970's.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Andrew Cunliffe.

SiteName: Site M (M-RABB, Jornada LTER, New Mexico)
community_description: Mesquite dunefield, relativly low stature mesquite.
community_species: Prosopis glandulosa, Atriplex canescens
phenology: Seasional peak biomass, following some large precipitation evens a few weeks previously.
soil: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, thermic Ustic Petroargids
disturbance: No known recent disturbance. Site was located on USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range. Grazing history is light to moderate domestic grazing historically. It has been light grazing since at least the 1970's. There is rotational grazing among fenced pastures, timing dependent on quantity and quality of forage. Cattle numbers on the range are reduced during drought and grass-stressed years.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Caiti Steele and Robert Wojcikiewicz.
Acknowledgements: funding Jornada LTER (NSF 1235828). Permission Jornada LTER and ARS (Study number 545). Assistance John Anderson, Qiuyan Yu, Julius Anchang, C. Wade Ross, Danielle Lara, Niall Hanan, Lara Prihodk PLUS TBC folks from NMSU.

SiteName: Site M (M-RABB, Jornada LTER, New Mexico)
community_description: Mesquite dunefield, relativly low stature mesquite.
community_species: Prosopis glandulosa, Atriplex canescens
phenology: Seasional peak biomass, following some large precipitation evens a few weeks previously.
soil: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive, thermic Ustic Petroargids
disturbance: No known recent disturbance. Site was located on USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range. Grazing history is light to moderate domestic grazing historically. disturbance: No known recent disturbance. Site was located on USDA-ARS Jornada Experimental Range. Grazing history is light to moderate domestic grazing historically. It has been light grazing since at least the 1970's. There is rotational grazing among fenced pastures, timing dependent on quantity and quality of forage. Cattle numbers on the range are reduced during drought and grass-stressed years.
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Species ID confirmed by Caiti Steele and Robert Wojcikiewicz.

SiteName: Site 2 - Cottage Flat (private land), Bredbo, NSW
community_description: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
community_species: Eragrostis curvula, Bothriochloa macra + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
soil: Moderately well-drained Yellow Earths (Gn2.42, Gn2.22) and Red Earths (Gn2.21) on lower slopes. Shallow <30-40cm
disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally shallow soil site with rocky outcrops.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741) to M.L.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud looks okay, corners are ca. 6 cm high, which will underestimate canopy height

SiteName: Site 2 - Cottage Flat (private land), Bredbo, NSW
community_description: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
community_species: Eragrostis curvula, Bothriochloa macra + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
soil: Moderately well-drained Yellow Earths (Gn2.42, Gn2.22) and Red Earths (Gn2.21) on lower slopes. Shallow <30-40cm
disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally shallow soil site with rocky outcrops.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741) to M.L.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy

SiteName: Site 1 - One Tree Hill (private land), Bredbo, NSW
community_description: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
community_species: Bothriochloa macra, Eragrostis curvula, Nassella trichotoma + 5-10 minor grass species + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
soil: shallow (<40 cm), rapidly drained Lithosols (Uc1.43, Um1.43), well-drained Red Earths (Gn2.12, Gn2.15, K-Gn2.12, K-Gn2.15) and moderately well-drained Non-calcic Brown Soils (Dr2.12) and Red Podzolic Soils (Dr2.52) on crests and upper slopes.
disturbance: Up to ~1980 was part of sheep grazing station, but generally lightly grazed due to location and distance to water source. Tree recruitment was still was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). No evidence of recent fire
Notes_on_survey_harvest: hill top site - very exposed, gets several snow falls each. year. Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).

Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741) to M.L.

Notes_on_survey_harvest: hill top site - very exposed, gets several snow falls each. year. Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).

SiteName: Site 1 - One Tree Hill (private land), Bredbo, NSW
community_description: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
community_species: Bothriochloa macra, Eragrostis curvula, Nassella trichotoma + 5-10 minor grass species + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.

disturbance: Up to ~1980 was part of sheep grazing station, but generally lightly grazed due to location and distance to water source. Tree recruitment was still was poor. SiteName: Site 3 - River End (private land), Bredbo, NSW
community_description: Snow gum (E. pauciflora) grassy woodland / Tableland Cool Temperate Grasslands
community_species: Juncus (mostly J. alexandri), Eragrostis curvula + 20-30+ minor herb/forb spp.
phenology: Late growing season - extreme drought conditions until recent snow/rain. Mixture of previous seasons growth and some new growth. Inflorescence/spikelets predominantly previous season.
soil: Moderately well-drained to imperfectly drained Alluvial Soils (NSG) of variable depth (10-100cm)
disturbance: Up to ~1980 primarily sheep grazing, during which trees were cleared and tree recruitment was poor. Since 1980 light grazing (e.g. few cattle) to no grazing except native herbivores (kangaroos, wombats etc.). Grass fire in previous year - likely june-aug 2018
Notes_on_survey_harvest: generally wet site on river alluvial plain, gets fairly consistent seepage from uphill slopes.  Climate: Temp = 19.4 (mean max); 4.2 (mean min). all the GNSS data is in EPSG:28355  thats the Australian UTM equivalent (all the survey gear and RTK correction services are set up for GDA94).
Acknowledgements: Australian Research Council (LP180100741)
Acknowledgements_Funding: Australian Research Council (LP180100741) to M.L.

SiteName: Taroudant (site IRG3c)
community_species: Argania spinosa (trees), Launaea arborescens (bushes)
phenology: Unusually dry after lack of winter rains - spring should be full leaf out condition for Argania spinosa, but many trees remain leafless this year. L. arborescens hardly has any leaves in the best of springs; shoot parts are drier this year than usual.
soil: Regosol, 25-30 cm (poorly developed soil on sedimentary fan)
disturbance: Goat, sheep and dromedar grazing and browsing.
Comp1: Partition A: small twigs and spiky shoot parts
Comp2: Partition B: woody stems and branches
Notes_on_survey_harvest:
"Kirchhoff, M., Engelmann, L., Zimmermann, L.L., Seeger, M., Marzolff, I., At Hssaine, A. & Ries, J.B. (2019): Geomorphodynamics in Argan Woodlands, South Morocco. Water 11(10):2193. DOI:10.3390/w11102193.

SiteName: Taroudant (site IRG3c)
community_species: Argania spinosa (trees), Launaea arborescens (bushes)
phenology: Unusually dry after lack of winter rains - spring should be full leaf out condition for Argania spinosa, but many trees remain leafless this year. L. arborescens hardly has any leaves in the best of springs; shoot parts are drier this year than usual.
soil: Regosol, 25-30 cm (poorly developed soil on sedimentary fan)
disturbance: Goat, sheep and dromedar grazing and browsing.
Comp1: Partition A: small twigs and spiky shoot parts
Comp2: Partition B: woody stems and branches

Investigators: Anne Griebel, Daniel Metzen, Matthias M. Boer
SiteName: Whitewater Stadium Penrith, New South Wales
community_description: mixed grassland dominated by two closely resembling species (Eragrostis curvula, Chloris gayana)
community_species: Eragrostis curvula, Chloris gayana
phenology: Near peak biomass following substantial rain events over the last month, ~1m tall mixed grassland, new growth of green stalks of both species with a relatively thick layer of dead grass stalks near the surface. We were unable to differentiate the two species in the field.
additional_species_in_plot: Domniated by Eragrostis curvula and Chloris gayana
soil: Unknown
disturbance: unmanaged section at the grounds of the whitewater rafting stadium from the 2000 Sydney olympics, was affected by severe drought but recovered after substantial rain
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Vegetation in photos appears to be less than 1 m high
Acknowledgements: Penrith Whitewater Stadium, Craig McNamara, Kathryn Fuller. NSW Department of Industry (NCRIS co-funding of Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network  Cumberland Plain Supersite) to M.M.B and A.G.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NSW Department of Industry (NCRIS co-funding of Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network  Cumberland Plain Supersite) to M.M.B and A.G.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud is terrible. Corners appear at least 0.8 m high.

phenology: Near peak biomass following substantial rain events over the last month, ~1m tall mixed grassland, new growth of green stalks of both species with a relatively thick layer of dead grass stalks near the surface. We were unable to differentiate the two species in the field.
additional_species_in_plot: Domniated by Eragrostis curvula and Chloris gayana
soil: Unknown
disturbance: unmanaged section at the grounds of the whitewater rafting stadium from the 2000 Sydney olympics, was affected by severe drought but recovered after substantial rain
Notes_on_survey_harvest: Vegetation in photos appears to be less than 1 m high
Acknowledgements: Penrith Whitewater Stadium, Craig McNamara, Kathryn Fuller. NSW Department of Industry (NCRIS co-funding of Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network  Cumberland Plain Supersite) to M.M.B and A.G.
Acknowledgements_Funding: NSW Department of Industry (NCRIS co-funding of Terrestrial Ecosystem Research Network  Cumberland Plain Supersite) to M.M.B and A.G.
Agreement: I/We agree to the data use and authorship policy
Notes_from_processing_and_review: Point cloud is terrible. Mostly gaps in the point cloud coverage. Corners could be plausible. Excluded from further analysis
